title: Rosie O’Donnell ‘Shocked’ by Her New Clothing Size After Dramatic Weight Loss
description: Rosie O’Donnell posted a photo of her dramatic weight loss on Instagram on Tuesday, Aug. 12. The 63-year-old comedian went on a shopping trip and discovered that she has gone down a clothing size.
content:
Rosie O'Donnell 's recent body transformation has left her stunned!

On Tuesday, Aug. 12, The alum, 63, shared her surprise in an Instagram post after discovering that she’d dropped a clothing size after trying on clothes at a store, following her recent weight loss.

“Ok, so [I] went shopping to buy a comfy lounge wear outfit for my 22-hour flight to Australia,” O’Donnell explained in the caption, while sharing a photo of herself sporting a black top and matching pants in the changing room.

“[I] was undecided as I can't see myself in this new smaller body,” she continued. “[My friends] took this photo of me in the dressing room — I am shocked I’m a 12 — #mounjaro is a life saver 🥹❤️🇮🇪.” 

 Never miss a story — sign up for to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories. 

O’Donnell has openly discussed her weight loss journey on social media. In January 2023, she shared on TikTok that she had started taking Mounjaro , an FDA-approved prescription medication for people with type 2 diabetes, which helps with weight loss by reducing appetite and improving how the body breaks down sugar and fat.

In March, the Emmy Award winner shared in an update on TikTok that she’d “lost more weight” since taking Mounjaro, following her recent move to Ireland with her 12-year-old child Clay .

“I’ve lost more weight. I am on Mounjaro for my diabetes and one of the side effects is you lose weight," said O’Donnell. "But it’s also because I had a chef for over two years in Los Angeles and I don't have a chef now. It's me cooking for Clay and me.” 

 ! 

The comedian said she went shopping in Dublin in search of clothes that “fit better” after slimming down. "I'm one of those people who always had a weight issue and now that I'm a size large — instead of an XL or a XXL — I find it shocking," said O'Donnell. "I really do."

O’Donnell’s latest post comes after she showed off her new slender appearance at the premiere in London in late July.

For the event, the comedian wore a gray blazer and black pants, both with New York-inspired graffiti artwork, over a black T-shirt with black boots and her signature glasses.
summary: Rosie O'Donnell, a 63-year-old comedian, has dropped a clothing size after undergoing a drastic weight loss. She shared her surprise in an Instagram post about her transformation in a black top and matching pants. The actress credits her weight loss to Mounjaro, an FDA-approved prescription medication for people with type 2 diabetes, which reduces appetite and improves how the body breaks down sugar and fat. O’Donnell also revealed that she has lost more weight since moving to Ireland with her child, Clay.
shortSummary: Rosie O’Donnell was shocked to discover she'd dropped a clothing size after trying out lounge wear, highlighting her recent weight loss via Mounjaro.

scraped_sources.text: The View Has a New State-of-the-Art Studio for Season 28: See Inside with PEOPLE's Exclusive First Look Photos Executive producer Brian Teta takes PEOPLE inside the space, and teases what's ahead at the Hot Topics table By Dave Quinn Dave Quinn Dave Quinn is the Deputy News Director at PEOPLE. He has been working at the brand since 2016, and is the author of the No. 1 New York Times best-selling book, Not All Diamonds and Rosé: The Inside Story of the Real Housewives from the People Who Lived It. People Editorial Guidelines Published on September 3, 2024 10:00AM EDT 2 Comments The View's new studio for season 28. Credit : AC/Michael Granacki The View's co-hosts are going to take a little time to enjoy a brand new view when the hit daytime series returns for season 28 on Tuesday, Sept. 3. Whoopi Goldberg, Joy Behar, Sara Haines, Sunny Hostin, Ana Navarro and Alyssa Farah Griffin will all be back for another season of Hot Topics. And while the iconic table remains the same, everything else around them has had a major upgrade. PEOPLE has an exclusive first look inside The View's new swanky state-of-the-art studio, located in the Walt Disney Company’s recently completed 22-story Manhattan headquarters in Hudson Square. The show is the first of ABC's to make the movie to the building, though won't be the last. Good Morning America, Live with Kelly and Mark and Tamron Hall are all expected to follow in the coming months. "It says a lot about Barbara Walters' original vision and the foundation they built that nearly three decades later, the show is not just more relevant that ever but the cornerstone of this exciting new venture by Disney," executive producer Brian Teta tells PEOPLE. "It really is an honor." 'The View' season 28 studio. AC/Michael Granacki Ryan Reynolds Makes Surprise Appearance in Audience of The View with His Mom: 'This Is Way Less Stressful' On a visit to the studio late last month, PEOPLE saw the technology at play first-hand, which will give the control room the ability to tap into unparalleled creative freedom and production flexibility. The room is covered in LED screens, including a floor that with the flick of a button can go from a herringbone wood pattern to images of flowing lava or an ocean swimming with sharks. "Our graphics team is like kids in the candy store right now," says Teta. "There's so much that we're still going to need to get acclimated with and play with. I think at first, it'll be The View you know and love, but as time goes on, we'll have a lot of fun with some of the things we can do." 'The View' season 28 studio. AC/Michael Granacki The View Teases Its 'Big Move' to a 'Hot New Studio' in Season 28 Promo (Exclusive) The set's cool color palette is similar to what fans have seen in recent seasons, with the addition of new elevated furniture to punch it up. "We kept the table, because that was new last year, and that remains the centerpiece as always," Teta explains. "But at the same time, everything around it is new and modern and sleek. It makes it familiar to what people like about The View, but also elevates it to the next level." Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories. 'The View' season 28 set. AC/Michael Granacki Sara Haines Playfully Confronts Her View Co-Host Alyssa Farah Griffin for Misspelling Her Name in Email The biggest change is a new two-story structure with a wrap-around staircase and an upper-level balcony. "The original set for The View was a loft, so there's a definite callback to that," Teta says. "And it's a place where I know we can play." Teta is vague about what the structure will eventually be used for, suggesting everything from musical performances introductions to interview segments. Goldberg might even appear there at the top of Tuesday's premiere. "We could put a DJ up there, there might be a reason to have guests up there, I can put Statler and Waldorf from the Muppets up there..." he teases. "We plan on having a lot of fun with it." 'The View' season 28 set. AC/Michael Granacki Perhaps for the most important new addition are six new teal chairs, which Teta says was the hardest thing to agree on because the co-hosts are so opinionated. "Listen, the great and difficult thing about this show is that they are built to be different perspectives. It's built into the hard wiring of what this show is," Teta said. "It's different people with different backgrounds, different perspectives, different ages — all those things. So getting them to agree on anything is a challenge, even seats. But it's also what makes the show so special." As for the audience, though the new studio seats a hair fewer people, Teta notes there's still over 100 spots for fans and the distance from the hosts are still the same, so it still feels intimate. "In fact, my podium is closer than ever before, so that's probably going to be my biggest adjustment," Teta says. "Towards the end of last season, a couple of times, I was talking to the control room and Whoopi would turn and say, 'You know, I just heard you.' So I got to soften my voice a little bit." Brian Teta on the season 28 set of 'The View'. AC/Michael Granacki Whoopi Goldberg 'Needed to Take a Breath' and Step Aside amid Chat About Foot Fetishes on The View Overall, Teta — who marks his 10th season with The View this year — says he's beyond impressed with the studio overall. "I've been in television for 25 years and it's one of the only times where I've been shown the plans for something and it's not only met the original vision, but really exceeded it." says Teta. "It's really terrific." "We looked at this, I think six months ago and I was like, 'Yeah, sure, if that actually happens, that will be phenomenal.' And then to walk in here and see what they've put together? It's really just such a phenomenal marvel of engineering and such a credit to the people who designed this, the crew who installed it, and everybody else involved." 'The View' season 28 studio. AC/Michael Granacki The View's studio isn't the only thing getting an upgrade for season 28. The show's official podcast, Behind the Table, will have a brand new studio too. "We're really excited about that," says Teta, who hosts the series. "We're going to have an actual set and video, which is terrific because we'll be able to post full episodes on YouTube for the first time, in addition to streaming podcast platforms." The podcast often features the co-hosts themselves, expanding on hot topics and also opening up about their own personal lives. Occasionally, guests from the main show stop by, too. "We'll try to bring in more guests throughout the season, because we've had a lot of fun doing that. But the co-hosts are our staple and they really love the show, despite them complaining constantly about it on air," Teta laughs. "It's nice for them. They get to speak uninterrupted and dive a little bit deeper on some of the topics that we don't necessarily the chance to do on the show." A glam touchup station in the new studio of 'The View'. AC/Michael Granacki Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson Says She Is 'Considering' Supporting an 'Enforceable' Supreme Court Ethics Code This aims to be a banner year for The View, which isn't just the most watched daytime talk show on TV but watched more than any other talk show in America, including late night. Once dubbed by the New York Times "the most important political show in America," the daytime show especially thrives in an election year and has a slew of political guests lined up for its first two weeks back. Among them include Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson (Wednesday, Sept. 4:), Gov. Josh Shapiro (Friday, Sept. 6) and Rep. Nancy Pelosi (Monday, Sept. 9). "It's under 70 days to the election and I couldn't be more fired up." Teta tells PEOPLE. "I know we've said this a couple of times in the past, but this is potentially the most consequential election in American history. And I'm excited to see who's going to come through the doors and be a guest in the next 70 days." The table has hosted every major political candidate in the past three decades. "No one has been elected president since George W. Bush without appearing on The View first," Teta says. "Even Trump in 2015 made a phone call. So the road to the White House goes through The View." 'The View' season 28 co-host photo (from left to right): Sunny Hostin, Joy Behar, Ana Navarro, Whoopi Goldberg, Sara Haines and Alyssa Farah Griffin. ABC/JEFF LIPSKY The View Co-Hosts Have a Group Text Thread but Whoopi Goldberg Keeps Removing Herself: 'I'm Busy' And just because The View co-hosts have been on break for the past few weeks doesn't mean they're not fired up and ready to go. "Everyone does their best to unplug for our vacation weeks, but I heard from the co-hosts constantly on a text chain, having their own Hot Topics arguments privately," Teta says. "I'm like, 'No one's paying you right now, guys. Just enjoy your vacation!' But they can't turn it off." That's why the first show back will be a full day of Hot Topics. "When we left the show, we didn't know who the Democratic vice presidential nominee was. There hadn't even been a Democratic convention yet. So there's so much to talk about," Teta explains. "So we're just going to let it rip." The View airs weekdays (11 a.m. ET) on ABC. Close Leave a Comment Read more: Entertainment TV Talk Shows

What to Know About Tirzepatide, the New Weight-Loss Drug Expected to Be Approved by the FDA This Year A clinical trial found that a high dose of tirzepatide — which was previously approved for diabetes treatment — helped patients lose an average of 22.5% of their body weight By Vanessa Etienne Vanessa Etienne Vanessa Etienne is an Emerging Content Writer-Reporter for PEOPLE. People Editorial Guidelines Published on January 2, 2023 04:53PM EST Man preparing semaglutide Ozempic injection. Credit : Getty Tirzepatide, a new drug that could have far-reaching impact — and billions in sales — is likely to be approved for weight loss by the Food and Drug Administration in 2023. The drug, made by U.S. pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly, is already approved by the FDA to treat Type 2 diabetes. However, at higher doses it has been proven to be highly effective for weight loss by reducing food intake and appetite and improving how the body breaks down sugar and fat. A clinical trial found that a high dose of tirzepatide helped patients lose about 52 pounds, or an average of 22.5% of their body weight. Tirzepatide, when approved by the FDA, is predicted to hit a record $48 billion in sales, Bank of America analyst Geoff Meacham told NBC News. While the drug is expected to gain tremendous popularity for weight loss, it is unlikely most people will be able to receive the prescription medication — taken by injection in the thigh, stomach or arm — through insurance companies. Lower doses of the drug, used to treat diabetes, are covered by most insurance companies. However, there is very minimal coverage for cases where the drugs are prescribed for obesity. Researchers estimate that tirzepatide could cost about $13,000 annually, or about $1,100 per month, NBC reports. Doctor Criticizes Trend of Using Diabetes Drugs for Weight Loss: 'People Who Need These Drugs Can't Get Them' What to Know About Plenity, the New Prescription Weight Loss Treatment Tirzepatide is the latest diabetes treatment that has been known to help with weight loss. Recently, Ozempic and Wegovy have been trending on social media after TikTok users speculated that a number of celebrities have used the drugs for weight loss, even though they don't have diabetes or clinical obesity. Further, Elon Musk tweeted earlier this month that he used Wegovy for his recent slimdown. Bravo's Andy Cohen also tweeted about the growing popularity of the drugs for weight loss. However, Dr. Caroline Apovian, co-director of the Center for Weight Management and Wellness at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, warned that use of these medications strictly for weight loss is causing less availability for "underserved" diabetic patients whose lives are at risk without the drugs. Ozempic and Wegovy are both listed as "currently on shortage" on the FDA's website. Novo Nordisk said in a release that the shortage is caused by a recent increase in demand, as well as supply chain issues. "The Hollywood trend is concerning," Apovian recently told PEOPLE. "We're not talking about stars who need to lose 10 pounds. We're talking about people who are dying of obesity, are going to die of obesity." "You're taking away from patients with diabetes," she continued. "We have lifesaving drugs… and the United States public that really needs these drugs can't get them." Rosie O'Donnell on the Moment Daughter Dakota Asked to Speak to Her Birth Mother: 'I Was in Tears' In this week's issue of PEOPLE, Rosie O'Donnell opens up in an emotional essay about her 9½-year-old daughter Dakota, who was diagnosed with autism in 2016 By Georgia Slater Georgia Slater Georgia Slater is a staff editor on the Parents team at PEOPLE. She has been working at PEOPLE since 2018. Her work has previously appeared in USA Today and Washington Life Magazine. People Editorial Guidelines and Liz McNeil Liz McNeil Liz McNeil is an Editor at Large at PEOPLE, where she's worked for over 30 years. People Editorial Guidelines Published on September 21, 2022 05:50PM EDT Rosie O'Donnell is opening up about the time her daughter Dakota requested to speak with her birth mother, whom she called "the lady whose tummy I was in." The TV personality, 60, recounts the moving moment in an emotional essay written in this week's issue of PEOPLE, out Friday. In the essay, O'Donnell shares her journey in raising her daughter Dakota, 9½, who was diagnosed with autism at age 2½ in 2016. O'Donnell, who describes her daughter as "endlessly curious," says Dakota asked to speak to her birth mother when she was 5 years old. "We're in contact, so Dakota gets on FaceTime and says, 'Are you the lady whose tummy I was in? I just wanted you to know I'm the kid that was in there, and when I got born, my mommy held me and I squeezed her pinkie, and I am with her. So I just want to let you know that's what happened to me. Bye,'" the actress recalls. Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from juicy celebrity news to compelling human interest stories. Chloe Aftel Rosie O'Donnell Opens Up About Her Daughter with Autism in Emotional Essay: 'She's a Gift' "I was in tears as was her birth mom," O'Donnell writes. "That's a pretty intense, complex, emotional thing for a little girl to put together." O'Donnell, who is also mom to Parker, 27, Chelsea, 25, Blake, 22, and Vivienne, 19, notes, "I think about the birth mothers every day." Chloe Aftel "I think about the generosity of human spirit that allows someone who knows they're not able at the moment to be a mom to this baby, give that baby all [they] deserve," she shares. "To place that child in the loving arms of a stranger." "It's the biggest act of generosity I think that humans can do. And I've been the benefactor of their selflessness and it made my life worth everything," says O'Donnell. "Nothing in my life ever compares to the five kids and nothing, no reward you ever win, no amount of money you ever get, can replace the love of family, and of a parent and a child." courtesy of Rosie O'Donnell O'Donnell, now starring in the Showtime series American Gigolo, explains that her daughter's autism has enriched her life in unexpected ways and "forces me to see the world from a completely different place." "She's a gift from another dimension. The things she knows — about sea anemones and tide pools. I got to 60 not knowing about the Mariana Trench," she continues. "Now I know all about it! Her ability to absorb information is unparalleled. I can imagine her winning on Jeopardy! someday." "She teaches me," O'Donnell concludes. "To be able to see the world as she does — for me, it's been a wonderfully magical experience. I'm so glad we have each other." argos_summary: Rosie O'Donnell recently expressed her surprise at her weight loss journey, revealing she has dropped to a size 12 after using the diabetes medication Mounjaro, which also aids in weight loss. In an Instagram post, she shared her shock at fitting into smaller clothes while preparing for a trip to Australia. O'Donnell has openly discussed her transformation, attributing her weight loss to both the medication and lifestyle changes, including cooking for herself and her child after moving to Ireland.
